original: 5. Sivirājacakkhudānapañha
translated: The Questions about the Gift of Eyes to King Sivi

original: “Bhante nāgasena, tumhe evaṁ bhaṇatha—
analyzed: bhante nāgasena tumhe evam bhaṇatha
translated: “Though you say this, revered Nāgasena,

original: ‘sivirājena yācakassa cakkhūni dinnāni, andhassa sato puna dibbacakkhūni uppannānī’ti,
analyzed: sivirājena yācakassa cakkhūni dinnāni andhassa sataḥ puna dibba cakkhūni uppannāni iti
translated: that King Sivi gave his eyes to the beggar and, though he was blind, his divine eye arose again,

original: etampi vacanaṁ sakasaṭaṁ saniggahaṁ sadosaṁ ‘hetusamugghāte ahetusmiṁ avatthusmiṁ
analyzed: etam pi vacanam sa kasaṭam sa niggaham sa dosam hetu samugghāte a hetusmin a vatthusmin
translated: this statement is self-contradictory, is inconclusive, is faulty, and is contrary to the suttas, which say: ‘When the cause is destroyed, there is no arising of the divine eye in the absence of a cause, in the absence of a basis.’

original: natthi dibbacakkhussa uppādo’ti sutte vuttaṁ, yadi, bhante nāgasena, sivirājena yācakassa🔽cakkhūni dinnāni, tena hi ‘puna dibbacakkhūni uppannānī’ti yaṁ vacanaṁ, taṁ micchā;
analyzed: natthi dibba cakkhussa uppādaḥ ti sutte vutta yadi bhante nāgasena sivi rājena yācakassa  cakkhūni dinnāni tena hi puna dibba cakkhūni uppannāni iti yam tam micchā
translated: If, revered Nāgasena, King Sivi gave his eyes to the beggar,🔽then the statement that his divine eye arose again is false.

original: yadi dibbacakkhūni uppannāni, tena hi ‘sivirājena yācakassa cakkhūni dinnānī’ti yaṁ vacanaṁ, tampi micchā.
analyzed: yadi dibba cakkhūni uppannāni tena hi sivi rājena yācakassa cakkhūni dinnāni iti yam micchā
translated: If his divine eye arose again, then the statement that King Sivi gave his eyes to the beggar is false.

original: Ayampi ubhato koṭiko pañho gaṇṭhitopi gaṇṭhitaro veṭhatopi veṭhataro gahanatopi gahanataro, so tavānuppatto, tattha chandamabhijanehi nibbāhanāya paravādānaṁ niggahāyā”ti.
analyzed: ayam pi ubhatas koṭiko pañhaḥ gaṇṭhitaḥ api gaṇṭhitaraḥ veṭhataḥ api veṭhataraḥ gahanataḥ api gahanataraḥ so tava anuppattaḥ tattha chandam abhijanehi nibbāhanāya paravādānam niggahāya ati
translated: This too is a double-pronged question, a knot, a puzzle, a riddle. It has come to you; now unravel it.”

original: “Dinnāni, mahārāja, sivirājena yācakassa cakkhūni, tattha mā vimatiṁ uppādehi, puna dibbāni ca cakkhūni uppannāni, tatthāpi mā vimatiṁ janehī”ti.
analyzed: dinnāni mahā rāja sivi rājena yācakassa cakkhūni tattha mā vimatim uppādehi puna dibbāni ca cakkhūni uppannāni tattha api mā vimatim janehi iti
translated: “The eyes of the beggar were given by King Sivi, sire, and you should not doubt that. And divine eyes have arisen to him; you should not doubt that either.”

original: “Api nu kho, bhante nāgasena, hetusamugghāte ahetusmiṁ avatthusmiṁ dibbacakkhu uppajjatī”ti?
analyzed: api nu kho bhante nāgasena hetu samugghāte ahetusmim avatthusmim dibba cakkhu uppajjati iti
translated: “But, revered Nāgasena, do divine eyes arise without a cause, without a reason, without a basis, when the cause has been removed?”

original: “Na hi, mahārājā”ti.
analyzed: na hi mahā rājāti
translated: “No, sire.”

original: “Kiṁ pana, bhante, ettha kāraṇaṁ, yena kāraṇena hetusamugghāte ahetusmiṁ avatthusmiṁ dibbacakkhu uppajjati, iṅgha tāva kāraṇena maṁ saññāpehī”ti?
analyzed: kim pana bhante ettha kāraṇa yena kāraṇena hetu samugghāte ahetusmim avatthusmim dibba cakkhu uppajjati iṅgha tāva kāraṇena mama saññāpehi iti
translated: “But what is the reason, revered sir, why divine eyes arise without a cause, without a reason, without a basis, when the cause has been removed? Explain that to me.”

original: “Kiṁ pana, mahārāja, atthi loke saccaṁ nāma, yena saccavādino saccakiriyaṁ karontī”ti?
analyzed: kim pana mahā rāja atthi loke saccam nāma yena sacca vādinaḥ sacca kiriyam karonti iti
translated: “But, sire, is there such a thing as truth in the world, by means of which truthful people perform the truth-act?”

original: “Āma, bhante, atthi loke saccaṁ nāma, saccena, bhante nāgasena, saccavādino saccakiriyaṁ
analyzed: āma bhante atthi loke saccam nāma saccena bhante nāgasena sacca vādinaḥ
translated: “Yes, revered sir, there is truth in the world. By means of truth, revered sir, those who speak the truth, having made a truth-act

original: katvā devaṁ vassāpenti, aggiṁ nibbāpenti, visaṁ paṭihananti, aññampi vividhaṁ kattabbaṁ karontī”ti.
analyzed: katvā devam vassāpenti aggim nibbāpenti visam paṭihananti aññam pi vividham kattabbam karonti iti
translated: cause the gods to rain, they extinguish fire, they counteract poison, and they do other various things that have to be done.”

original: “Tena hi, mahārāja, yujjati sameti sivirājassa saccabalena dibbacakkhūni uppannānīti,🔽saccabalena, mahārāja, avatthusmiṁ dibbacakkhu uppajjati, saccaṁyeva tattha vatthu
analyzed: tena hi mahā rāja yujjati sameti sivi rājassa sacca balena dibba cakkhūni uppannāni iti  sacca balena mahā rāja avatthusmim dibba cakkhu uppajjati saccayā iva tattha vatthu
translated: “Well then, sire, it is proper to say that the divine eye arose in Sivi king through the power of truth.

original: bhavati dibbacakkhussa uppādāya.
analyzed: bhavati dibba cakkhussa uppādāya
translated: Through the power of truth, sire, the divine eye arises in the absence of a basis. Truth itself is the basis there for the arising of the divine eye.

original: Yathā, mahārāja, ye keci sattā saccamanugāyanti ‘mahāmegho pavassatū’ti, tesaṁ saha
analyzed: yathā mahā rāja ye keci sattā saccam anugāyanti mahā meghaḥ pavassatu uti tesam saha
translated: As, sire, whatever beings sing the truth, ‘Let a great cloud rain down,’ for them a great cloud rains down

original: saccamanugītena mahāmegho pavassati, api nu kho, mahārāja, atthi ākāse vassahetu
analyzed: saccamanugītena mahā meghaḥ pavassati api nu kho mahā rāja atthi ākāse vassa hetu
translated: simultaneously with the singing of the truth. Now, sire, is there a cause for rain stored up in the sky

original: sannicito ‘yena hetunā mahāmegho pavassatī’”ti?
analyzed: sannicitaḥ yena hetunā mahā meghaḥ pavassati iti
translated: by reason of which a great cloud rains down?”

original: “Na hi, bhante, saccaṁyeva tattha hetu bhavati mahato meghassa pavassanāyā”ti.
analyzed: na hi bhante saccayā iva tattha hetu bhavati mahataḥ meghassa pavassanāya ati
translated: “No, revered sir, truth itself is the cause there for the raining down of a great cloud.”

original: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, natthi tassa pakatihetu, saccaṁ yevettha vatthu bhavati dibbacakkhussa uppādāyāti.🔽Yathā vā pana, mahārāja, ye keci sattā saccamanugāyanti ‘jalitapajjalitamahāaggikkhandho
analyzed: evam eva kho mahā rāja na atthi tassa pakati hetu saccam yā iva ittha vatthu bhavati dibba cakkhussa uppādāya ati  yathā vā pana mahā rāja ye keci sattā saccam anugāyanti jalita pajjalita mahā aggi kkhandhaḥ
translated: “So too, sire, there is no natural cause for the arising of the divine eye, the truth of the matter is that there is a basis for the arising of the divine eye.”

original: paṭinivattatū’ti, tesaṁ saha saccamanugītena jalitapajjalitamahāaggikkhandho khaṇena paṭinivattati.
analyzed: paṭinivattatu uti tesam saha saccam anugītena jalita pajjalita mahā aggi khandhaḥ khaṇena paṭinivattati
translated: “As, sire, whatever beings sing the truth, ‘Let the great mass of fire, burning and blazing, turn back,’ the great mass of fire, burning and blazing, turns back the moment they sing the truth.

original: Api nu kho, mahārāja, atthi tasmiṁ jalitapajjalite mahāaggikkhandhe hetu sannicito ‘yena hetunā jalitapajjalitamahāaggikkhandho khaṇena paṭinivattatī’”ti?
analyzed: api nu khalu mahā rāja atthi tasmin jalita pajjalite mahā aggi kkhandhe hetu sannicitaḥ yena hetunā jalita pajjalita mahā aggi kkhandhaḥ khaṇena paṭinivattati iti
translated: Now, sire, is there any cause stored up in that great mass of fire, burning and blazing, by reason of which the great mass of fire, burning and blazing, turns back the moment it is sung?”

original: “Na hi, bhante, saccaṁyeva tattha vatthu hoti tassa jalitapajjalitassa mahāaggikkhandhassa khaṇena paṭinivattanāyā”ti.
analyzed: na hi bhante saccayā iva tattha vatthu hoti tassa jalita pajjalitassa mahā aggi khandhassa khaṇena paṭinivattanāya ati
translated: “No, revered sir, the truth of the matter is that there is a basis for the turning back of that great mass of fire, burning and blazing.”

original: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, natthi tassa pakatihetu, saccaṁ yevettha vatthu bhavati dibbacakkhussa uppādāyāti.
analyzed: evam eva kho mahā rāja na atthi tassa pakati hetu saccam yā iva ittha vatthu bhavati dibba cakkhussa uppādāya ati
translated: “So too, sire, there is no natural cause for the arising of the divine eye, the truth of the matter is that there is a basis for the arising of the divine eye.”

original: Yathā vā pana, mahārāja, ye keci sattā saccamanugāyanti ‘visaṁ halāhalaṁ agadaṁ bhavatū’ti.
analyzed: yathā vā pana mahā rāja ye keci sattā saccam anugāyanti visam halāhalam agadam bhavatu uti
translated: Or, sire, whatever beings chant the truth, saying, ‘Let the poison halāhala become harmless,’

original: Tesaṁ saha saccamanugītena visaṁ halāhalaṁ khaṇena agadaṁ bhavati, api nu kho, mahārāja,🔽atthi tasmiṁ halāhalavise hetu sannicito ‘yena hetunā visaṁ halāhalaṁ khaṇena agadaṁ bhavatī’”ti?
analyzed: tesam saha saccam anugītena visam halāhalam khaṇena agadam bhavati api nu kho mahā rāja  atthi tasmin halāhala vise hetu sannicitaḥ yena hetunā visam halāhalam khaṇena agadam bhavati iti
translated: does that poison halāhala become harmless immediately on their chanting the truth?

original: “Na hi, bhante, saccaṁyeva tattha hetu bhavati visassa halāhalassa khaṇena paṭighātāyā”ti.
analyzed: na hi bhante saccayā iva tattha hetu bhavati visassa halāhalassa khaṇena paṭighātāya ati
translated: “No, revered sir, the truth is the only cause there for the immediate counteraction of the poison halāhala.”

original: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, vinā pakatihetuṁ saccaṁ yevettha vatthu bhavati dibbacakkhussa uppādāyāti.🔽Catunnampi, mahārāja, ariyasaccānaṁ paṭivedhāya natthaññaṁ vatthu, saccaṁ vatthuṁ katvā cattāri ariyasaccāni paṭivijjhantīti.
analyzed: evam eva kho mahā rāja vinā pakati hetum saccam yā iva ittha vatthu bhavati dibba cakkhussa uppādāya ati  catunnam pi mahā rāja ariya saccānam paṭivedhāya natthaññam vatthu saccam vatthum katvā cattāri ariya saccāni paṭivijjhanti iti
translated: “Even so, sire, apart from the natural cause, the truth is the only cause here for the arising of the deva eye.🔽For the penetration of the four noble truths, sire, there is no other cause than the truth. Having made the truth the cause, the four noble truths are penetrated.

original: Atthi, mahārāja, cīnavisaye cīnarājā, so mahāsamudde kīḷitukāmo catumāse catumāse
analyzed: atthi mahā rāja cīna visaye cīna rājā saḥ mahā samudde kīḷitu kāmo catu māse catu māse
translated: There is, sire, a king of the Cīnas, and he, desiring to sport in the great ocean, every four months

original: saccakiriyaṁ katvā saha rathena antomahāsamudde yojanaṁ pavisati, tassa rathasīsassa
analyzed: saccakiriyam katvā saha rathena antar mahā samudde yojanam pavisati tassa ratha sīsassa
translated: and after performing the truth-act, he entered the great ocean for a league with his chariot,🔽then a great mass of water receded in front of the chariot’s

original: purato purato mahāvārikkhandho paṭikkamati, nikkhantassa puna ottharati, api nu kho,
analyzed: puratas puratas mahāvāri khandhaḥ paṭikkamati nikkhantassa punar ottharati api nu kho
translated: front wheel, and when he came out it flooded over him again.

original: mahārāja, so mahāsamuddo sadevamanussenapi lokena pakatikāyabalena sakkā paṭikkamāpetun”ti?
analyzed: mahā rāja saḥ mahā samuddaḥ sa deva manussena api lokena pakati kāya balena sakkā paṭikkamāpetun ti
translated: Would it be possible, Great King, for that great ocean to be made to recede by the world with its gods and men by means of natural physical strength?”

original: “Atiparittakepi, bhante, taḷāke udakaṁ na sakkā sadevamanussenapi lokena pakatikāyabalena paṭikkamāpetuṁ, kiṁ pana mahāsamudde udakan”ti?
analyzed: ati parittake pi bhante taḷāke udakam na sakkā sa deva manussena api lokena pakati kāya balena paṭikkamāpetu kim pana mahā samudde udakam ti
translated: “Venerable Sir, it is not possible for the water in even a very small pond to be made to recede by the world with its gods and men by means of natural physical strength, so how could it be possible in the great ocean?”

original: “Imināpi, mahārāja, kāraṇena saccabalaṁ ñātabbaṁ ‘natthi taṁ ṭhānaṁ, yaṁ saccena na pattabban’ti.🔽Nagare, mahārāja, pāṭaliputte asoko dhammarājā sanegamajānapadaamaccabhaṭabalamahāmattehi
analyzed: iminā api mahā rāja kāraṇena sacca balam ñātabbam natthi tat yat saccena na pattabbanti  nagare mahā rāja pāṭaliputte asokaḥ dhamma rājā sa negama jānapada amacca bhaṭabala mahāmattehi
translated: “For this reason, Great King, the power of truth should be known: ‘There is no place that cannot be reached by means of truth.’🔽In the city of Pāṭaliputta, Great King, King Aśoka, the Just, surrounded by his ministers, the chief of whom was Rādhagupta,

original: parivuto gaṅgaṁ nadiṁ navasalilasampuṇṇaṁ samatitthikaṁ sambharitaṁ pañcayojanasatāyāmaṁ
analyzed: parivutaḥ gaṅgam nadim nava salila sampuṇṇam sama titthikam sambharitam pañca yojana sata āyāma
translated: and by his army of foot-soldiers, cavalry, chariots and elephants, and by the people of the town and the country,🔽went to the river Gaṅgā, which was full of fresh water, with a good ford, and was five hundred leagues long,

original: yojanaputhulaṁ sandamānaṁ disvā amacce evamāha—
analyzed: yojana puthulam sandamānam disvā amacce evam āha
translated: and seeing the river flowing a league wide, he said to his ministers:

original: ‘atthi koci, bhaṇe, samattho, yo imaṁ mahāgaṅgaṁ paṭisotaṁ sandāpetun’ti.
analyzed: atthi koci bhaṇe samatthaḥ yaḥ imam mahāgaṅgam paṭisotam sandāpetunti
translated: ‘Is there anyone, my good men, who can make this great river flow backwards?’

original: Amaccā āhaṁsu ‘dukkaraṁ, devā’ti.
analyzed: amaccā āhasu dukkara deva ati
translated: The ministers said, ‘It’s difficult, your Majesty.’

original: Tasmiṁyeva gaṅgākūle ṭhitā bandhumatī nāma gaṇikā assosi raññā kira evaṁ vuttaṁ—
analyzed: tasmiyā eva gaṅgā kūle ṭhitā bandhumatī nāma gaṇikā assosi raññā kira evam vutta
translated: Standing on the bank of the river, a courtesan called Bandhumatī heard the King say this.

original: ‘sakkā nu kho imaṁ mahāgaṅgaṁ paṭisotaṁ sandāpetun’ti, sā evamāha—
analyzed: sakkā nu khalu imam mahāgaṅgam paṭisotam sandāpetunti sā evam āha
translated: ‘Is it possible to make this great river flow backwards?’ She said,

original: ‘ahañhi nagare pāṭaliputte gaṇikā rūpūpajīvinī antimajīvikā, mama tāva rājā saccakiriyaṁ passatū’ti.
analyzed: aham hi nagare pāṭaliputte gaṇikā rūpa upajīvinī antima jīvikā mama tāva rājā sacca kiriyam passatu uti
translated: ‘I am a courtesan in the city of Pāṭaliputta, who makes a living from my beauty and youth. Let the King see my act of truth.’

original: Atha sā saccakiriyaṁ akāsi, saha tassā saccakiriyāya khaṇena sā mahāgaṅgā gaḷagaḷāyantī paṭisotaṁ sandittha mahato janakāyassa passato.
analyzed: atha sā saccakiriyam akāsi saha tassā saccakiriyāya khaṇena sā mahāgaṅgā gaḷagaḷāyantī paṭisotam mahataḥ jana kāyassa passato
translated: And she performed her act of truth. At that moment, the great river flowed backwards, right before the eyes of the crowd.

original: Atha rājā gaṅgāya āvaṭṭaūmivegajanitaṁ halāhalasaddaṁ sutvā vimhito acchariyabbhutajāto amacce evamāha—
analyzed: atha rājā gaṅgāya āvaṭṭa ūmi vega janitam halāhala saddam sutvā vimhitaḥ acchariya bbhuta jātaḥ amacce evam āha
translated: Then the King, hearing the sound of the river’s waters rushing back up the stream, was amazed and astonished. He said to his ministers:

original: ‘kissāyaṁ, bhaṇe, mahāgaṅgā paṭisotaṁ sandatī’ti?
analyzed: kissāya bhaṇe mahāgaṅgā paṭisotam sandati iti
translated: ‘Why is this great river flowing backwards, my good men?’

original: ‘Bandhumatī, mahārāja, gaṇikā tava vacanaṁ sutvā saccakiriyaṁ akāsi, tassā saccakiriyāya mahāgaṅgā uddhammukhā sandatī’ti.
analyzed: bandhumatī mahā rāja gaṇikā tava vacanam sutvā saccakiriyam akāsi tassā saccakiriyāya mahāgaṅgā uddham mukhā sandati iti
translated: ‘Bandhumatī, great king, the courtesan, after hearing your words, made an act of truth, and through the power of her act of truth, the great Ganges flowed upstream.’

original: Atha saṁviggahadayo rājā turitaturito sayaṁ gantvā taṁ gaṇikaṁ pucchi—
analyzed: atha sa vigga hadayaḥ rājā turita turitaḥ sayam gantvā tam gaṇikam pucchi
translated: Then, with a troubled heart, the king hurried there himself and asked the courtesan,

original: ‘saccaṁ kira, je, tayā saccakiriyāya ayaṁ gaṅgā paṭisotaṁ sandāpitā’ti?
analyzed: saccam kira je tayā saccakiriyāya ayam gaṅgā paṭisotam sandāpitā ati
translated: ‘Is it true, my lady, that you made the Ganges flow upstream through an act of truth?’

original: ‘Āma, devā’ti.
analyzed: āma deva ati
translated: ‘Yes, your majesty.’

original: Rājā āha—
analyzed: rājā āha
translated: The king said,

original: ‘kiṁ te tattha balaṁ atthi, ko vā te vacanaṁ ādiyati anummatto, kena tvaṁ balena imaṁ mahāgaṅgaṁ paṭisotaṁ sandāpesī’ti?
analyzed: kim te tattha balam atthi kaḥ vā te vacanam ādiyati anummatto kena tvam balena imam mahāgaṅgam paṭisotam sandāpesi iti
translated: ‘What power do you have there, or who believes your words? By what power did you make this great Ganges flow upstream?’

original: Sā āha—
analyzed: sā āha
translated: She said,

original: ‘saccabalenāhaṁ, mahārāja, imaṁ mahāgaṅgaṁ paṭisotaṁ sandāpesin’ti.
analyzed: saccabalena āha mahā rāja imam mahāgaṅgam paṭisotam sandāpesinti
translated: ‘By the power of truth, great king, I made this great Ganges flow upstream.’

original: Rājā āha—
analyzed: rājā āha
translated: The king said,

original: ‘kiṁ te saccabalaṁ atthi coriyā dhuttiyā asatiyā chinnikāya pāpiyā bhinnasīlāya hiriatikkantikāya andhajanapalobhikāyā’ti.
analyzed: kim te sacca balam atthi coriyā dhuttiyā asatiyā chinnikāya pāpiyā bhinna sīlāya hiri atikkantikāya andha jana palobhikāya ati
translated: ‘What power of truth do you have, you thief, you cheat, you liar, you cutter of good things, you wicked one, you one of broken virtue, you one who has gone beyond shame, you one who deceives the blind?’

original: ‘Saccaṁ, mahārāja, tādisikā ahaṁ, tādisikāyapi me, mahārāja, saccakiriyā atthi, yāyāhaṁ icchamānā sadevakampi lokaṁ parivatteyyan’ti.
analyzed: sat ca mahā rāja tādisikā aha me mahā rāja sacca kiriyā atthi yāyā aham icchamānā sa devakam pi lokam
translated: ‘It is true, sire, I am such a one, and I have a power of truth, by which, if I so wish, I could make the world with its gods revolve.’

original: Rājā āha—
analyzed: rājā āha
translated: The king said:

original: ‘katamā pana sā hoti saccakiriyā, iṅgha maṁ sāvehī’ti.
analyzed: katamā pana sā hoti saccakiriyā iṅgha mama sā āvehi iti
translated: ‘But what is this power of truth? Show me.’

original: ‘Yo me, mahārāja, dhanaṁ deti khattiyo vā brāhmaṇo vā vesso vā suddo vā añño vā koci,
analyzed: yaḥ me mahā rāja dhanam deti khattiyaḥ vā brāhmaṇaḥ vā vessaḥ vā suddaḥ vā aññaḥ vā koci
translated: ‘Sire, whatever Khattiya or Brahmin or Vessan or Suddan or any other gives me wealth,

original: tesaṁ samakaṁyeva upaṭṭhahāmi, “khattiyo”ti viseso natthi, “suddo”ti atimaññanā natthi,
analyzed: tesam samakayā iva upaṭṭhahāmi khattiyaḥ ti visesaḥ natthi suddo ti atimaññanā natthi
translated: I serve them all equally, without making any distinction, thinking: “This is a Khattiya,” or “This is a Suddan.”

original: anunayappaṭighavippamuttā dhanassāmikaṁ paricarāmi, esā me, deva, saccakiriyā, yāyāhaṁ
analyzed: anunaya ppaṭigha vippamuttā dhana ssāmikam paricarāmi esā me deva sacca kiriyā yāya āha
translated: I serve them all without attachment or aversion, and this is my power of truth, sire, by which

original: imaṁ mahāgaṅgaṁ paṭisotaṁ sandāpesin’ti.
analyzed: imam mahāgaṅgam paṭisotam sandāpesinti
translated: I can make the great river flow upstream.’

original: Itipi, mahārāja, sacce ṭhitā na kiñci atthaṁ na vindanti.
analyzed: mahā rāja sacce ṭhitāḥ na kiñci attham na vindanti
translated: Thus, sire, those who stand on truth find no difficulty in achieving anything.

original: Dinnāni ca, mahārāja, sivirājena yācakassa cakkhūni, dibbacakkhūni ca uppannāni, tañca saccakiriyāya.
analyzed: dinnāni ca mahā rāja sivi rājena yācakassa cakkhūni dibba cakkhūni ca uppannāni tat ca sacca kiriyāya
translated: And, sire, the eyes that were given by King Sivi to the beggar were replaced by divine eyes, and that was through the power of truth.

original: Yaṁ pana sutte vuttaṁ—
analyzed: yam pana sutte
translated: But it is said in the scriptures:

original: ‘maṁsacakkhusmiṁ naṭṭhe ahetusmiṁ avatthusmiṁ natthi dibbacakkhussa uppādo’ti.
analyzed: masa cakkhusmiṃ naṭṭhe ahetusmim avatthusmim natthi dibba cakkhussa uppādaḥ ti
translated: ‘When the fleshly eye is destroyed, without cause, without basis, there is no arising of the divine eye.’

original: Taṁ bhāvanāmayaṁ cakkhuṁ sandhāya vuttaṁ, evametaṁ, mahārāja, dhārehī”ti.
analyzed: tam bhāvanā mayam cakkhum sandhāya vuttaḥ evam eta mahā rāja dhārehi iti
translated: This is the eye that is meant by the word ‘development,’ so you should bear it in mind, sire.”

original: “Sādhu, bhante nāgasena, sunibbeṭhito pañho, suniddiṭṭho niggaho, sumadditā paravādā, evametaṁ tathā sampaṭicchāmī”ti.
analyzed: sādhu bhante nāgasena su nibbeṭhitaḥ pañhaḥ su niddiṭṭhaḥ niggahaḥ su maddi tā paravādāḥ evam etam tathā sampaṭicchāmi iti
translated: “Excellent, revered Nāgasena; the question has been well analysed, the difficulty has been well resolved, the arguments of others have been well demolished. So it is, therefore do I accept this explanation.”

original: Sivirājacakkhudānapañho pañcamo.
